Posts.Content: My PSA was rising after surgery, but before Lupron and radiation, which were done together. So I was never on Lupron alone. With a few weeks to go in radiation, I was at .02, which was encouraging (but not 0!). I feel good energy-wise, in pretty good shape, did a 5 mile hike on Sunday. Bowels have been frequent and loose (or worse) during the treatment, but cutting caffeine helped a lot. They say I should be back to "normal" in 2-4 weeks, at least from the radiation effects. I literally had my morning routine down to the minute to walk into radiation full but not so full I lost it. (which happened once; embarrassing!)
Posts.Signature: DOB-9/21/1958, 57 at the time of my surgery PSA Feb 2, 2016 = 7.1 MRI March 2 = definite tumor on right lobe Biopsy March 17 - targeted with MRI rendering, 15 cores, 10 positive Gleason 3+5=8 (right side aggressive, starting to invade the capsule). Bone scan 4/13, negative RALP surgery 5/16/2016. Extra urethra taken (suspicious), sphincter saved. Home 5/17. Pathology: lymph nodes clean, right lobe negative margin, left lobe small positive margin. Possible remaining cancer. 8/26/2016: @ three months: PSA 0.03. 11/18/2016: @ six months: PSA 0.26 <-- still have cancer, referred to a Radiation Oncologist DEC 9, begin 6 month course of Lupron (shot) + Casodex (pill). 39/39 radiation sessiongs completed. Next four tests <.01 -- .03 -- .58 -- 2.7 -- PSMA-PET scan on 7/17/18 -- current test 13.5 Recovery from surgery: 95%. Recovery from radiation: 70%, sexual and minor continence problems.

Posts.Content: I used the large bag at night, the smaller one wouldn't have held it all and the tube was too short to hang by the bed. I used Neosporin, Vaseline didn't help me with the chafing. I used a (very) clean fingertip to apply. Just keep everything VERY clean and get through it. Those were some of the most horrible ten days of my life. I know some of the guys seem to have an easier time with it, but I was not happy until it came out!

Posts.Content: I meant "0" to be the same as "undetectable". My understanding is that any measurable PSA more than a few months after RP is cancer. I would love to be wrong about that! I already know that what was left behind in me was aggressive, as it had a one month doubling rate. So I'm concerned with any number right now. My main side effect from Lupron is the hot flashes. I have them pretty often, and it does mess with my sleeping a little. Besides the other huge effect on libido, it's not a problem. I also have some very minor bowel problems (smaller, looser, more often) from the radiation. Over all, the greatest challenge is having empy bowels and a completely full bladder at a specific time every day. (This helps move that stuff aside and away from the beam). Very uncomfortable!

Posts.Content: Had my DaVinci on Monday, came home yesterday. I was much more confident thanks to all of you. My first post was "post-op questions". So I had my surgery done at Santa Monica UCLA. Dr. Chamie is my Urologist and Dr. Wong did anaethesia. He had to take a little extra urethra because it looked suspicious for cancer outside the prostate, but he did save my sphincter. Also took a bunch of lymph nodes. I was unconscious before reaching the operating room, so I didn't get to meet my machine. Spent one night in the hospital (ZERO sleep thanks to some nurse or whoever coming in every 30 minutes), and was discharged yesterday. Six incision sites. So now its pain control (hydrocodone) and getting used to this annoying catheter and bag (comes out on May 26, next Thursday). I'm eating okay but haven't had a BM yet; I hope that happens today, I think I'll be more comfortable. Anyone get referred shoulder pain? Maybe from gas/pressure; it can be as bad as the incision sites. I'll post my progress in this thread as I recover. Thanks again guys, now we wait and see if they got it all. Fingers crossed. I need to know which brand of diaper is best, what did you all use? Is Tenna good? I have a coupon, lol.

Posts.Title: and its done! I'm post-op

Posts.Content: Had my DaVinci on Monday, came home yesterday. I was much more confident thanks to all of you. My first post was "post-op questions". So I had my surgery done at Santa Monica UCLA. Dr. Chamie is my Urologist and Dr. Wong did anaethesia. He had to take a little extra urethra because it looked suspicious for cancer outside the prostate, but he did save my sphincter. Also took a bunch of lymph nodes. I was unconscious before reaching the operating room, so I didn't get to meet my machine. Spent one night in the hospital (ZERO sleep thanks to some nurse or whoever coming in every 30 minutes), and was discharged yesterday. Six incision sites. So now its pain control (hydrocodone) and getting used to this annoying catheter and bag (comes out on May 26, next Thursday). I'm eating okay but haven't had a BM yet; I hope that happens today, I think I'll be more comfortable. Anyone get referred shoulder pain? Maybe from gas/pressure; it can be as bad as the incision sites. I'll post my progress in this thread as I recover. Thanks again guys, now we wait and see if they got it all. Fingers crossed. I need to know which brand of diaper is best, what did you all use? Is Tenna good? I have a coupon, lol.

Posts.Content: Doctor said to use over the counter laxative, and that 3-4 days for a BM was normal. I'm just not going to stress over it. I took my outer stomach bandages off per instructions today, and some of the Steristrips came with them. They don't tell you that might happen; it was because of the dried blood. So in a couple of places I have Bandaids and Neosporin; no big deal but thought others might want to know. Sitting isn't real comfortable; I find myself pacing around a lot. Looking forward to night #2 at home.

Posts.Title: and its done! I'm post-op

Posts.Content: If this is posted somewhere as a thread, just point me there, and thanks. I'm 57, I have PSA 7.1 and a Gleason of 8. I'm quite healthy and fit in every other way. My most aggressive tumor is pushing out towards one of the nerve bundles. My consultation today was a recommendation for robotic abdominal surgery, which I probably will do. I opted out of radiation because (1) you have no recourse if you're in the 20% and get the cancer again and (2) bad effects increase over time (more or less). He said if I were 80, radiation might make more sense. My doctor seemed to paint a rosier picture than most recovery descriptions I read online. What are men's real life experiences? He says one night in the hospital (not 2), catheter for one week (not 2-4), back at work in two weeks (I have a desk job), and urinary control most likely after a month. Sexual function may take a while or be compromised forever, I understand that. What say you?

Posts.Title: follow up on me, mixed news

Posts.Content: Hi all, It's always been a safe zone to come here and report in. (especially when I first found out). Surgery didn't get all of it (RALP, PSA rising after surgery) Radiation didn't get all of it (40 treatments + Lupron) Last 3-month tests were .03 .15 .57 2.7 So now we are doing a PSMA scan, which is new and very sensitive, and may be able to locate remaining cancer. There are only a few of these machines in the country, and insurance doesn't cover it. Worth it I think to buy the best scan I can get. Possible surgery (lymph node, for example) or radiation (if it's on a bone) if found. Otherwise, more waiting and scanning. So, that's where I'm at. All with a disease I've never felt a single symptom from. This adventure continues!

Posts.Content: Thanks chiguy. I think that study is for people pre-surgery who are in the MRI/biopsy phase. And my Gleason was 7 This patient population will have low (1 = Gleason 3 + 3) or intermediate risk (2 = 3 + 4; 3 = 4 + 3) prostate cancer. Patients will be scheduled for a (magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as part of routine care for either surgical planning or for further biopsy.

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael, I will check it out. The study is by "invitation only" (in those studies the population and participants are pre-chosen). My Uro said exactly what you did; that location is important now (and why I'm getting the more sensitive scan). He had one case where the remaining cancer was sitting on a single lymph node, which he took out. That patient has a consistent low PSA now. I'm focused on that scenario!

Posts.Title: First Post Op PSA Test

Posts.Content: L-Citrulline along with low dose Cialis help bring blood flow to the penis. My Uro recommended it for before and after my surgery. I began 5mg Cialis and 3000mg L-Citrulline a month before surgery. I will continue it post-op for three months. (I'm almost two weeks post-op) I was able to get partial erections with the catheter still in and full ones the day after it came out (10 days post-op). I don't know what role the L-Citrulline played in that recovery, but I say it can't hurt!

Posts.Content: I got my PSMA-PET scan on 7/17 with PSA of 2.7. The scan is sensitive down to 0.2 -- and it found nothing! This was a very unusual result with that scan for a rising PSA at that level. So.....just posting that the scan (out of pocket cost!) isn't perfect -- now we go back to PSA every three months and see what happens. The good news is also that nothing lit up; so there was no evidence of metastatic cancer at all. To be continued...

Posts.Title: PSMA scan

Posts.Content: Thanks. I am two years post surgery and more than a year post radiation. It's very unlikely that any healthy prostate tissue remains and, that wouldn't explain a rising PSA anyway. The scan I had is sensitive to 0.2 PSA. The study has 800 subjects. The researcher who consulted me and my Uro think either my cancer cells are unreactive with the compound, or my cancer cells are near a well vascularized area, making my PSA "artificially" high (since PSA is only done through a blood test). Like I said... to be continued!
